brief_summary.textblock:
Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD) feature impairments in social interaction and communication.
      Drug and behavioral treatments for ASD are undergoing rapid development, yet our diagnostic
      tools are not suitable for efficacy assessment. The Autism-Diagnosis Observational Schedule
      (ADOS) is a clinical interview with the child and the gold standard for diagnosis. However,
      this test is subjective, course grained and costly, precluding repeated tests of the same
      child to assess treatment efficacy and large-scale control assessments of typically
      developing (TD) children. For these reasons, the ADOS can impede imaging and genetic
      research.

      In light of these concerns, the Oregon Animation Test for Social Reciprocity (OATS) will be
      developed to evaluate distinct autistic behavioral phenotypes, including joint attention,
      empathy, imitation, and lack of narrative coherence. The main idea of OATS is that animated
      characters and social scenarios are presented on a computer screen while the responses of
      the child are recorded by video camera, microphone, and eye-tracking equipment. Animations
      are used to test each behavioral phenotype of autism. The long-term vision for OATS is to
      evaluate behavioral and physiological responses of autistic children, including heart
      rate variability, pupil dilation, and EEG. Our first objective is to use existing animations
      to build an OATS "Prototype" that discriminates autistic from normal children (Aim 1). From
      these results, and use of a defined library of still frame posed images, we will design our
      own animation platform to assess differences between autistic and normal children (Aim 2).

clinical_study.brief_title: Novel Measure of Social Deficits in Children

detailed_description.textblock: Please see the brief summary above.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  6-11 years of age with autism,

          -  ADHD, or typical

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  IQ below 70.

study_pop.textblock: Children 6-11 years of age with autism, ADHD, or typical, with and IQ exceeding 70.

clinical_study.official_title: Oregon Animation Test for Social Reciprocity (OATS)

other_outcome.description: A child is shown an animation and is asked to recount the story.
other_outcome.measure: Ability to recount a story shown via animation

other_outcome.description: A child is shown an animation and is asked to imitate a character's action .
other_outcome.measure: Ability to imitate an action shown via animation

primary_outcome.measure: Eye gaze in response to animated social situations

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: A child is shown an animation and facial expressions are coded for various emotions.
secondary_outcome.measure: Facial expressions in response to animated social situations

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case Control, Time Perspective: Prospective
